newsitem.title: BELGIUM: NATO-Russia move closer to enlargement deal.
newsitem.headline: NATO-Russia move closer to enlargement deal.

text.p: NATO and Russia have moved closer to a groundbreaking deal on a new post-Cold War relationship though major problems still cloud the alliance's eastwards expansion, alliance sources said on Monday.
"The pace is quickening, we share a great deal of common ground," one source said.
He was commenting after the latest round of talks between NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana and Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov which ended late on Sunday.

NATO sources said the two sides had agreed on the need to set up a permanent consulatative mechanism to govern future relations. Russia had expressed a preference for this to be enshrined in a new document rather than a NATO-proposed charter.
A new joint Russia-NATO Council would be separate to NATO with its own secretariat in which both sides would have an equal voice, they added.
"We are drawing closer together on the idea of a distinct NATO-Russia consultative council," one source said.
A brief joint communique issued after the talks at Solana's private residence said progress had been made at the talks although differences remained. It gave no other details.

Alliance sources said Russia was still pushing for a legally binding document whereas NATO preferred a more flexible political commitment and was seeking assurances new military equipment would not be placed on the territory of new members.

NATO sources say any final NATO-Russia document could be endorsed by heads of state and government at a summit in Madrid next July at which NATO will invite some former Warsaw Pact states to join the alliance.

"It would in itself be a solemn and very important document," another source said. NATO is concerned that a legal document would take years to be ratified by all the alliance's 16 member parliaments, a tactic favoured by Russia to delay expansion.
President Boris Yeltsin accepted on Sunday enlargement may go ahead, but said his country's plan was to stall it as long as possible.
Senior NATO sources cautioned no major breakthrough could be expected in the near future, but said a real dialogue had no started after months of shadow-boxing.
"The Russians want to engage, and are serious," one official said.

Primakov declined to talk to reporters during his visit to Brussels. Early on Monday, a black limousine swept the former Cold War spy-master to a private aircraft waiting in a secluded corner of Brussels airport. He left shortly afterwards.
Before his talks started, Yeltsin, speaking in Moscow, gave the clearest hint yet the pace of the negotiations was hotting up.
Making his first public appearance since his bout of pneumonia at the New Year, Yeltsin said he expected a compromise to be struck during his summit with U.S. President Bill Clinton next month.
He said Moscow would continue its resistance to NATO expansion but then told reporters at a Kremlin wreath-laying:
"We have agreed to look for a compromise and I think we will find this compromise at the summit we are holding with President Clinton on March 20-21."

While NATO insists it will not let Moscow have a veto over who can join the alliance, it has offered a range of measures to try to reassure Russia that the admission of former Soviet satellites on its western flank will not be a security threat.

It would like to set down an agreement guaranteeing Russia a place in the new European security architecture before the July summit when the alliance is expected to invite Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic to join.
